original: Accounts payable or AP is an amount that a company needs to give to vendors for goods and services purchased on credit. It has to be paid off to its creditors or suppliers within a period. Accounts payable is a type of existing liability of a company.
result: Accounts payable refers to the amount that a business owes to vendors for goods and services purchased on credit. This represents an existing liability that must be paid by the company to its creditors or suppliers within a specified timeframe.

original: In other words, we can say that accounts payable is due money which the company has to pay to the vendors or suppliers for goods or services received that have not yet been paid for. Accounts Payable is considered as a liability and comes under the head 'current liabilities'. It is a short-term debt payment that needs to be paid to avoid default.
result: Accounts payable refers to the amount owed by a company to its suppliers or vendors for goods and services received but not yet paid for. It is a current liability and is considered a short-term debt that needs to be paid to avoid default. In other words, it is the money that a company owes to its vendors or suppliers for their products or services.

original: For example,  suppose a restaurant orders food and beverage from a company on credit to owe money to the company. These items are part of the inventory and are considered trade payables. On the other hand, the restaurant's obligations to other companies, such as the company cleaning the restaurant's staff uniforms, are considered accounts payable. Generally, both categories fall under the broader accounts payable category, and many companies combine both under the term accounts payable.
result: Let's consider a scenario where a restaurant buys food and beverages from a company on credit basis. In this case, the restaurant owes money to the company which falls under the category of trade payables. Meanwhile, there may be other obligations that the restaurant has to fulfill with various companies such as cleaning uniforms for staff, which are classified as accounts payable. Although both of these categories come under the broader term of accounts payable, some companies may simply refer to them using this single term.

result: TDS is an initialism used to denote Tax Deducted at Source, which is applied on the Base Amount. It is a straightforward process of deducting tax. Whenever a party (also known as the deductor) is obligated to pay another party (also referred to as the deductee), the deductor will subtract the TDS and transmit the balance payment to the deductee. The TDS sum is subsequently sent to the Central Government.

original: Following is a list of significant differences between debenture holders and preference shareholders:
result: The following outlines notable distinctions between preference shareholders and debenture holders.

original: A person having the debentures (has owed money to a company) is called a debenture holder.
result: A debenture holder is an individual who holds debentures, which represents an owed debt to a company.

original: A person holding the shares is called a preference shareholder. A shareholder could be considered as a partial owner of the company.
result: A preference shareholder refers to an individual who possesses shares in a company. Shareholders can be deemed as co-owners of the company.

original: A debenture holder needs to be paid money irrespective of the company making profits or losses.
result: The holder of a debenture is entitled to receive payment regardless of the financial performance of the company they have invested in.

original: A preference shareholder earns dividends if the company is making profits.
result: If an individual is a preference shareholder, they are entitled to receive dividend payments only if the company is profitable.

original: A debenture holder is only a creditor of the company.
result: A holder of a debenture simply holds a debt position with respect to the company and is not considered an owner of the company.

original: A preference shareholder is the joint owner of the company.
result: A shareholder who holds preference shares is considered as a co-owner of the company.

original: A debenture holder earns interest on the capital invested till the capital is not returned or gets the capital invested at the end of a stipulated term.
result: When someone invests in a debenture, they receive interest on their investment until the capital is repaid or until the end of the agreed term.

original: A preference shareholder is not always promised a return of the capital invested. Instead, he earns dividends till the time the company exists and is profitable.
result: A shareholder who holds preference shares does not have a guaranteed return on their investment. They receive dividends as long as the company remains profitable and in existence.

original: The debenture holders are not invited to attend the company's annual general meeting unless any decision affecting their interest is taken.
result: Debenture holders are not allowed to participate in the company's annual general meeting except if there is any matter impacting their stakeholder rights and interests.

original: The preference shareholders are always invited to attend the annual general meeting of the company.
result: The company usually extends an invitation to the preference shareholders to attend the annual general meeting.

original: The debenture holders cannot interfere with the management and regulation of the company.
result: Debenture holders do not have the authority to meddle with the company's management and governance.

original: The shareholders can control the affairs of the company. It is managed by the Board of Directors and the elected representatives of the shareholders.
result: The company's affairs are controlled by its shareholders, who elect representatives to the Board of Directors to manage its operations.

original: Debentures can be converted into shares.
result: It is possible to exchange debentures for shares through a process known as conversion.

original: Shares cannot be converted into debentures.
result: It is not possible to change or exchange shares for debentures.

original: Debentures are generally secured and carry a charge on the assets of the company. So, the debenture holder is paid before a shareholder winding up the company.
result: Debentures are typically backed by collateral and have a claim on the company's assets. This means that in the event of liquidation, the debenture holder's claims are prioritized over those of shareholders.

original: The shares don't have such a charge. So, the share capital is not returned except in the case of redeemable preference shares.
result: Unlike some other financial instruments, shares don't come with a charge to return the capital invested. This means that in most cases, the money invested in shares cannot be returned to the investor, unless the shares in question are redeemable preference shares.
